marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Merchant, governor of Massachusetts, and Signer of the Declaration of Independence.

Letter, 1774, from Captain James Scott to Col. John Hancock, reporting the safe arrival of the ship Hayley and commenting on reaction to the Boston Tea Party in London; letter, 1779, from William Lee to John Hancock concerning his movements and his plans for defending New York City and discussing the treatment of Tories in the area. Also receipts for pew rent, postage, bridge tolls, and taxes, some pertaining to Torry Hancock.

Letters and papers concerning routine military matters, including a letter from General Elijah Clark, 1788, requesting state troops for Franklin County, Ga., to protect people while gathering their crops; and extracts from the minutes of meetings of the Executive Council of Georgia, 1785.
Revolutionary soldier, governor of Georgia, from Augusta (Richmond Co.), Ga.
Official papers of Hanson as Chancellor of Maryland.
Correspondence among members of the Hanner family concerning family matters, agricultural productivity, migration to the western United States, and land and commodity prices.
Receipts and other business papers of Nathaniel A. Hammer, overseer of roads in Guilford County, North Carolina.

Letters of Hammond, including one to R. H. Wilde concerning the purchase of a slave and hiring an overseer; and one to F. W. Pickens giving his theory of government. Other letters, to William B. Hodgson, are concerned with the state of the nation, crops, prices of slaves, real estate, Hodgson's literary efforts, and religion. The collection also contains letters written to James H. Hammond's son Claudius Marcellus Hammond from members of his family commenting on the Civil War and Reconstruction. There are also 9 letters written by Hammond's eldest son, Harry, to his wife Emily, during his service in Virginia (1862-1863) with the Confederate army; the letters discuss daily life in camp and camp conditions, as well as Confederate and Union troop movements.
Lawyer, U.S. Congressman, 1835-1836; governor of South Carolina, 1842-1844; and U.S. Senator, 1857-1860; from Newberry District, S.C.
Letters from Oliver T. Hammond, principal of the Union Seminary at Norwich, to John F. Hubbard, concerning the advantages of Yale University as an educational institution.

Personal correspondence of William R. Hansford, a Confederate soldier, including comments on the yellow fever epidemic in Portsmouth in 1855, and the robbery and assault of a white girl by Negroes in Mobile in 1864.
Ezekiah and John Harding were residents of Clover Depot, Virginia.

Business letters of the mercantile firm of E. and J. Harding and of its branch firms at Danville, Pleasant Grove (Lunenburg County), and Moore's Ordinary, all in Virginia. Included are invoices for liquor, a few dealers' circulars, and one letter of a Confederate soldier, dated January 17, 1865, mentioning scarcity of food, low morale among the soldiers, and their hope for the immediate fall of Fort Fisher and the end of the war.
Union soldier from Marshall County, W. Va.
Mostly Civil War letters of John W. Harbison of the 12th West Virginia Regiment, concerning campaigns in western Virginia.

Miscellaneous papers of E. D. Hampton, sheriff of Davidson county, including a letter, 1857, from Philip T. Hay, a student at the University of North Carolina, concerning one of his slaves who was in the Davidson county jail; letter, 1860, commenting on the presidential election; letters concerning land and business matters; and a handbill, 1868, advocating disenfranchisement of the Negro in North Carolina.

Letters of O. Victor Hancock to his father concerning his job and tobacco prices in Richmond and, later, his experiences in the Civil War, including letters from Manassas, Camp Ewell, and Leesburg describing trench graves, camp life, and sickness among the soldiers.
Confederate soldier from Davie County, N.C.
Letters of a soldier in the 4th North Carolina Regiment concerning camp life in North Carolina and Virginia.
Lawyer and judge of Thomasville (Thomas Co.), Ga.
Collection contains two of Hansell's letters, one concerning Confederate recruitment and local defense in Georgia, and the other responding to a request for an autograph.
Haywood Hardy was a resident of Martinsburg, Va.
Letters of Confederate soldiers Haywood and W. D. Hardy to their father. One letter concerns the battle of Sharpsburg, and the other discusses feelings about reenlistment.
Union Army officer, from Montgomery Co., Pa.

Mainly copies of letters from George G. Meade to Hancock explaining why he did not engage Robert E. Lee's Confederate forces in the early fall of 1863 and announcing the promotion of Hancock and others, 1864; correspondence regarding the part played by the 56th Pennsylvania Regiment at the battle of the Wilderness; and a series of letters from Hancock to Philippe Albert d'Orleans, Comte de Paris, concerning Civil War materials. The bulk of the material dates from 1863-1885. There is one letter, dated 1843, regarding military transfer and leave procedures.
Confederate brigadier general, from Selma (Dallas Co.), Ala.

Correspondence and papers, including a letter, 1863, written from Tullahoma, Tenn., to Lieut. Col. George W. Brent, giving a full account of the Confederate maneuvers after the campaign in Kentucky; a receipt given Major Norman B. Smith for a mule; a memorandum, 1864, by Hardee concerning troop movements near Savannah; a letter, 1865, to Hardee from Gen. Joseph Wheeler about Confederate and Union troop movements in South Carolina; and a business letter, 1871, to John L. Bridgers, of Tarboro, N.C.
Sarah P. Harden was a resident of Henry County, Indiana.
Family correspondence of Sarah P. Harden, John Harden, Mary Harden, and Ann Harden to their aunt and uncle, Sarah and John Hackett, in one of the Carolinas.
Letters to Hammond from William Pinckney Starke discussing his impressions of Urbana University, Urbana, Ohio; politics in Ohio and elections of 1874; and racial attitudes in Ohio.
Letter from Jack Hannibal, a freedman, to his former owner.
Letters by Marcus Alonzo Hanna dealing with the selection of a picture of William McKinley for a volume of memorial addresses.
